title: Don Masson
text:
Donald Sandison Masson (born 26 August 1946 in <a href="Banchory">Banchory</a>) is a Scottish former <a href="association%20football">footballer</a>.
Club career.
Masson began his career with <a href="Middlesbrough%20F.C.">Middlesbrough</a> in 1964. He was signed by <a href="Notts%20County">Notts County</a> manager <a href="Billy%20Gray%20%28footballer%29">Billy Gray</a> in 1968 in a joint deal for £7000 along with <a href="Bob%20Worthington%20%28footballer%29">Bob Worthington</a>. He stayed there for six years before moving to <a href="Queens%20Park%20Rangers">Queens Park Rangers</a> in December 1974 for £100,000. Masson made his debut in the 1-0 home win versus Sheffield United on 14 December 1974.
Although approaching 29 years of age before he played top-level football, his was a signing that underlined the quality of then manager <a href="Dave%20Sexton">Dave Sexton</a>'s judgement. A stylish and creative <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a>, he came to be seen as the final piece in the jigsaw of an exciting and attacking QPR team. The following 1975/76 season saw QPR come close to winning the League title, being pipped by a point by <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a>.
After three years at <a href="Loftus%20Road">Loftus Road</a> he moved to <a href="Derby%20County%20F.C.">Derby County</a> in October 1977 in exchange for <a href="Leighton%20James">Leighton James</a>. After a further spell at Notts County he played for a time in the United States. Don was voted Notts best player of all time by Notts County supporters and also has a lounge at <a href="Meadow%20Lane">Meadow Lane</a> named in his honour. On returning to England he became the player-manager of <a href="Kettering%20Town">Kettering Town</a>, before retiring from the game.
International career.
Masson won 17 caps for <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a>. He scored five goals including Scotland’s first goal in the 2-1 victory over England in 1976 which clinched their first British Home International Championship since 1967. He missed a <a href="Penalty%20kick%20%28association%20football%29">penalty kick</a> in the 3–1 defeat against <a href="Peru%20national%20football%20team">Peru</a> in the <a href="1978%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1978 World Cup</a>.
Retirement.
In retirement he turned his hand in to the hotel business, having bought "The Gallery" at <a href="Trent%20Bridge">Trent Bridge</a>, <a href="Nottingham">Nottingham</a>, which he later sold. He and his wife now run The Grange, a guest house in <a href="Elton%20on%20the%20Hill">Elton on the Hill</a>.
